values.description:
This adds the ability to convert SDF to URDF. There is a command line tool that you can use: `ign sdf -u <sdf_filename>`.

I need to add a few more tests, and some numerical values are being converted to `inf` or `-nan`.
values.title: [WIP] Sdf2urdf

I need to add a few more tests, and some numerical values are being converted to `inf` or `-nan`.

values.description:
While reviewing pull request #468, I found some failing test cases:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=166)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/166/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/166/testReport/(root)/DOMLink/LinkChain/

Currently pose data is stored as `Matrix4d` in the vertices of the frame graph, but coordinate transformations really occur along the edges of the frame graph. This pull request refactors a bit so that the edges store a `Matrix4d`. The vertices still store pose data, but also have the pose frame now too. With these changes, the `LinkChain` test is now passing.

There were a few expectations in the `FourBar` test that were wrong, so I fixed those too, and added some more expectations for good measure.

There is quite a bit of duplicated code for doing this pose math in Collision.cc, Joint.cc, Link.cc, Model.cc, and Visual.cc. We could consider creating a `Frame` class to hold this logic.

Also, the `SetPose` methods update the Vertex pose data but don't update the `Matrix4d`s in the edges. This is marked as a `TODO`.
values.title: Refactor Pose dom: store Matrix4d in edges instead of vertices

summary.raw:
While reviewing pull request #468, I found some failing test cases:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=166)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/166/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/166/testReport/(root)/DOMLink/LinkChain/

Currently pose data is stored as `Matrix4d` in the vertices of the frame graph, but coordinate transformations really occur along the edges of the frame graph. This pull request refactors a bit so that the edges store a `Matrix4d`. The vertices still store pose data, but also have the pose frame now too. With these changes, the `LinkChain` test is now passing.

There were a few expectations in the `FourBar` test that were wrong, so I fixed those too, and added some more expectations for good measure.

There is quite a bit of duplicated code for doing this pose math in Collision.cc, Joint.cc, Link.cc, Model.cc, and Visual.cc. We could consider creating a `Frame` class to hold this logic.

Also, the `SetPose` methods update the Vertex pose data but don't update the `Matrix4d`s in the edges. This is marked as a `TODO`.
summary.html:
While reviewing pull request #468, I found some failing test cases:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/166/testReport/(root)/DOMLink/LinkChain/

Currently pose data is stored as Matrix4d in the vertices of the frame graph, but coordinate transformations really occur along the edges of the frame graph. This pull request refactors a bit so that the edges store a Matrix4d. The vertices still store pose data, but also have the pose frame now too. With these changes, the LinkChain test is now passing.

There were a few expectations in the FourBar test that were wrong, so I fixed those too, and added some more expectations for good measure.

There is quite a bit of duplicated code for doing this pose math in Collision.cc, Joint.cc, Link.cc, Model.cc, and Visual.cc. We could consider creating a Frame class to hold this logic.

Also, the SetPose methods update the Vertex pose data but don't update the Matrix4ds in the edges. This is marked as a TODO.

values.description:
Hi all,

I am currently in need of this keys to use the simulation, so I can set the erp and cmf parameters of each joint separately for the constrained axis.

So I did this little modification to implement this on the urdf parser, and I would need this to be added on the official gazebo repo for ubuntu 16.04 considering the libsdfformat.so.4.

Do you have other ideas to solve my problem? If not, how should I proceed to pursue this pull request.

Thanks,  
Ivan
values.title: Addition of ERP and CFM keys on urdf parser

values.description:
The material element is extended to support common Physically Based Rendering \(PBR\) parameters. The new `<pbr>` element is optional as the extension aims to be backward compatible with the existing SDF 1.6 spec.

There are two types of PBR workflows \(see [element description](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/258ac02ff2709c510744b7908ca952ffdd3c4343/sdf/1.6/material.sdf#lines-49)\), e.g. OGRE 2.1 and Unity supports both, while Unreal and Threejs use the Metallic/Roughness workflow. Typically, the user should stick to the same workflow for all materials in the entire scene.

Pros and Cons of the new spec:

**Pros**: Stricter spec, makes validation easier. Less confusion as to what params are needed in each workflow.

**Cons**: A few elements are duplicated. The users may not know which workflow to use or what the underlying renderer support. In this case, the user could just specify using the old way \(without `<pbr`\) or specify both and let the renderer choose. 

Appreciate any feedback on improving the spec
values.title: Add PBR material spec

summary.raw:
The material element is extended to support common Physically Based Rendering \(PBR\) parameters. The new `<pbr>` element is optional as the extension aims to be backward compatible with the existing SDF 1.6 spec.

There are two types of PBR workflows \(see [element description](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/258ac02ff2709c510744b7908ca952ffdd3c4343/sdf/1.6/material.sdf#lines-49)\), e.g. OGRE 2.1 and Unity supports both, while Unreal and Threejs use the Metallic/Roughness workflow. Typically, the user should stick to the same workflow for all materials in the entire scene.

Pros and Cons of the new spec:

**Pros**: Stricter spec, makes validation easier. Less confusion as to what params are needed in each workflow.

**Cons**: A few elements are duplicated. The users may not know which workflow to use or what the underlying renderer support. In this case, the user could just specify using the old way \(without `<pbr`\) or specify both and let the renderer choose. 

Appreciate any feedback on improving the spec
summary.html:
The material element is extended to support common Physically Based Rendering (PBR) parameters. The new <pbr> element is optional as the extension aims to be backward compatible with the existing SDF 1.6 spec.

There are two types of PBR workflows (see element description), e.g. OGRE 2.1 and Unity supports both, while Unreal and Threejs use the Metallic/Roughness workflow. Typically, the user should stick to the same workflow for all materials in the entire scene.

Pros and Cons of the new spec:

Pros: Stricter spec, makes validation easier. Less confusion as to what params are needed in each workflow.

Cons: A few elements are duplicated. The users may not know which workflow to use or what the underlying renderer support. In this case, the user could just specify using the old way (without <pbr) or specify both and let the renderer choose.

Appreciate any feedback on improving the spec

values.description:
Adding `sdf::Battery` for `<battery>` tag under `<link>`.

This is dependency for porting LinearBatteryPlugin and LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin from Gazebo classic to Ignition. Tested in [the port](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/234/acropolis-port-battery-plugin-from-gazebo/diff).

Adding `sdf::Battery` for `<battery>` tag under `<link>`.

This is dependency for porting LinearBatteryPlugin and LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin from Gazebo classic to Ignition. Tested in [the port](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/234/acropolis-port-battery-plugin-from-gazebo/diff).
summary.html:
Adding sdf::Battery for <battery> tag under <link>.

This is dependency for porting LinearBatteryPlugin and LinearBatteryConsumerPlugin from Gazebo classic to Ignition. Tested in the port.

values.reason: I’m going to decline this per recent discussions regarding ign-gazebo PR 234. We won’t be using SDF tags for battery, to be flexible to changes in the plugin implementation (as there are still features in the planning stage) and be independent to API/ABI.

values.description:
There is a windows warning related to the use of `tolower`, which outputs an `int`.

~~~
warning C4244: '=': conversion from 'int' to 'char', possible loss of data
src\Noise.cc(115): note: see reference to function template instantiation '_OutIt std::transform<std::_String_iterator<std::_String_val<std::_Simple_types<_Ty>>>,std::_String_iterator<std::_String_val<std::_Simple_types<_Ty>>>,int(__cdecl *)(int)>(const _InIt,const _InIt,_OutIt,_Fn)' being compiled
        with
        [
            _OutIt=std::_String_iterator<std::_String_val<std::_Simple_types<char>>>,
            _Ty=char,
            _InIt=std::_String_iterator<std::_String_val<std::_Simple_types<char>>>,
            _Fn=int (__cdecl *)(int)
        ]
~~~

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-sdformat8-windows7-amd64&build=12)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-sdformat8-windows7-amd64/12/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_windows/job/sdformat-ci-sdformat8-windows7-amd64/12/warnings42Result/

I've added a lambda as suggested [here](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/solutions/33196/view.html) but changed it to use `unsigned char` based on the recommendation of [cppreference](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/byte/tolower).

[![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64&build=630)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/630/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/630/

It kinda takes the fun out of that concise bit of code. :(
values.title: Fix Windows warning, use lambda function to cast output of tolower to unsigned char

[![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64&build=630)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/630/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/630/

warning C4244: '=': conversion from 'int' to 'char', possible loss of data
src\Noise.cc(115): note: see reference to function template instantiation '_OutIt std::transform<std::_String_iterator<std::_String_val<std::_Simple_types<_Ty>>>,std::_String_iterator<std::_String_val<std::_Simple_types<_Ty>>>,int(__cdecl *)(int)>(const _InIt,const _InIt,_OutIt,_Fn)' being compiled

I've added a lambda as suggested here but changed it to use unsigned char based on the recommendation of cppreference.

https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/630/

It kinda takes the fun out of that concise bit of code. :(

values.title: Rule of five for various DOM classes

summary.html:
This PR adds missing constructors and assignment operators to various DOM classes to comply with the rule of five. I believe the violation of this rule has led to test failures in this PR. The failures are segfaults and they arise when std::swap is used in resizing a std::vector containing DOM classes (more precisely, ign-gazebo components containing DOM classes).

Here is possible implementation of std::swap: 

void swap(T &_a, T &_b)
T tmp = std::move(_a);
_a = std::move(_b);
_b = std::move(_a);

Since a copy assignment is used if a move assignment is missing, some DOM classes will use a move constructor in T tmp = std::move(_a); and a copy assignment in a = std::move(_b). This leads to a segfault because the dataPtr in _a is set to nullptr when it was moved from.

The fix is to allocate a new dataPtr in copy assignment functions if its nullptr. Note that this problem wouldn't have surfaced if the class had a move assignment operator, so I added a test that explicitly exercises a copy assignment on an object that has been moved from.

values.description:
We'd like to make some structural changes to `noise.sdf` which requires a new version of the spec. 

This PR lays the groundwork by copying the 1.6 specification forward.

When this goes in, I'll make the following change to `noise.sdf`:

```
<noise>
    <gaussian>
        <mean>0.0</mean>
        <stddev>1.0</stddev>
    </gaussian>
    <static_bias>
        <mean>0.0</mean>
        <stddev>1.0</stddev>
     </static_bias>
     <dynamic_bias>
         <stddev>1.0</stddev>
         <correlation_time>3600</correlation_time>
     </dynamic_bias>
     <quantization>
         <precision>1e-6</precision>
      </quantization>
</noise>
```
values.title: [Citadel] Added sdf specification 1.7

summary.raw:
We'd like to make some structural changes to `noise.sdf` which requires a new version of the spec. 

This PR lays the groundwork by copying the 1.6 specification forward.

When this goes in, I'll make the following change to `noise.sdf`:

```
<noise>
    <gaussian>
        <mean>0.0</mean>
        <stddev>1.0</stddev>
    </gaussian>
    <static_bias>
        <mean>0.0</mean>
        <stddev>1.0</stddev>
     </static_bias>
     <dynamic_bias>
         <stddev>1.0</stddev>
         <correlation_time>3600</correlation_time>
     </dynamic_bias>
     <quantization>
         <precision>1e-6</precision>
      </quantization>
</noise>
```
summary.html:
We'd like to make some structural changes to noise.sdf which requires a new version of the spec.

This PR lays the groundwork by copying the 1.6 specification forward.

When this goes in, I'll make the following change to noise.sdf:

<noise>
    <gaussian>
        <mean>0.0</mean>
        <stddev>1.0</stddev>
    </gaussian>
    <static_bias>
        <mean>0.0</mean>
        <stddev>1.0</stddev>
     </static_bias>
     <dynamic_bias>
         <stddev>1.0</stddev>
         <correlation_time>3600</correlation_time>
     </dynamic_bias>
     <quantization>
         <precision>1e-6</precision>
      </quantization>
</noise>

values.description:
The `sdformat8-sdf` deb conflicts with `sdformat-sdf` from libsdformat6 due to the sdf files all being installed in `/usr/share/sdformat`. This can't just be changed by moving the install location in the debian metadata; the `SDF.cc` file needs to be recompiled to look in the updated location.

It's very late to merge this for blueprint, and it changes install locations, so it's questionable whether it should be merged to `sdf8`, but the sdformat package conflict is a bit nasty, so I think it would good to resolve it.
values.title: Install sdf files in versioned folder to allow debs to install side-by-side

summary.raw:
The `sdformat8-sdf` deb conflicts with `sdformat-sdf` from libsdformat6 due to the sdf files all being installed in `/usr/share/sdformat`. This can't just be changed by moving the install location in the debian metadata; the `SDF.cc` file needs to be recompiled to look in the updated location.

It's very late to merge this for blueprint, and it changes install locations, so it's questionable whether it should be merged to `sdf8`, but the sdformat package conflict is a bit nasty, so I think it would good to resolve it.
summary.html:
The sdformat8-sdf deb conflicts with sdformat-sdf from libsdformat6 due to the sdf files all being installed in /usr/share/sdformat. This can't just be changed by moving the install location in the debian metadata; the SDF.cc file needs to be recompiled to look in the updated location.

It's very late to merge this for blueprint, and it changes install locations, so it's questionable whether it should be merged to sdf8, but the sdformat package conflict is a bit nasty, so I think it would good to resolve it.

values.description: sdf8: prepare for 8.1.0 stable release

summary.raw: sdf8: prepare for 8.1.0 stable release
summary.html: sdf8: prepare for 8.1.0 stable release

values.description:
** Post Blueprint Release **

This adds an RGBD camera sensor type. This is the most basic change I could make in order to support a sensor type that produces both a RGB image, DepthImage, and PointCloud.

Not sure if this will break ABI compatibility.
values.title: Adding rgbd sensor type

summary.raw:
** Post Blueprint Release **

This adds an RGBD camera sensor type. This is the most basic change I could make in order to support a sensor type that produces both a RGB image, DepthImage, and PointCloud.

Not sure if this will break ABI compatibility.
summary.html:
Post Blueprint Release

This adds an RGBD camera sensor type. This is the most basic change I could make in order to support a sensor type that produces both a RGB image, DepthImage, and PointCloud.

Not sure if this will break ABI compatibility.

values.description:
Similar to [ign-msgs PR 137](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/137/pipeline-use-lcov-tag-v114/diff):

`make coverage` has been failing in the pipelines recently (see  0e8ef20); it looks like there was a recently change to lcov, so I've changed the script to clone a tag instead of the master branch

Error message I found in local testing:

~~~
Can't locate PerlIO/gzip.pm in @INC (you may need to install the PerlIO::gzip module) (@INC contains: /etc/perl /usr/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/perl/5.26.1 /usr/local/share/perl/5.26.1 /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/perl5/5.26 /usr/share/
~~~

Related commit: https://github.com/linux-test-project/lcov/commit/75fbae1cfc5027f818a0bb865bf6f96fab3202da
values.title: pipeline: use lcov tag v1.14

values.description:
similar to [ign-msgs PR 126](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/126/generalize-cmake-code-for-ign-tool-command/diff)

There is a pull request to add `ignition-tools` as a dependency of the sdformat7 formula, but the ign tests currently fail:

* https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/666
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64&build=564)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/564/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/564/testReport/

the tests pass with this branch

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64&build=563)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/563/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/563/
values.title: fix ign tool on macOS by melding cmake from ign-transport

values.description: I was trying to build sdformat on windows in a colcon workspace and had forgotten to install ruby, but colcon wasn't showing the `BUILD WARNINGS` and `BUILD ERRORS` section like it does for the ignition packages. It looks like colcon only prints the messages that are directed to `std_err`, so I've removed the `STATUS` keyword from the corresponding `message()` calls and added some formatting to match the ignition packages.
values.title: Print cmake build warnings and errors to std_err

summary.raw: I was trying to build sdformat on windows in a colcon workspace and had forgotten to install ruby, but colcon wasn't showing the `BUILD WARNINGS` and `BUILD ERRORS` section like it does for the ignition packages. It looks like colcon only prints the messages that are directed to `std_err`, so I've removed the `STATUS` keyword from the corresponding `message()` calls and added some formatting to match the ignition packages.
summary.html: I was trying to build sdformat on windows in a colcon workspace and had forgotten to install ruby, but colcon wasn't showing the BUILD WARNINGS and BUILD ERRORS section like it does for the ignition packages. It looks like colcon only prints the messages that are directed to std_err, so I've removed the STATUS keyword from the corresponding message() calls and added some formatting to match the ignition packages.

values.description:
Backport from sdf8:

* use cmake 3.5.1, major version in project name (sdformat7), use cmake targets and improve cmake config file generation

* changes to sdf specification from sdf8 (mostly sensors)
values.title: Backport from sdf8 -> sdf7: cmake and sdf spec changes

summary.raw:
Backport from sdf8:

* use cmake 3.5.1, major version in project name (sdformat7), use cmake targets and improve cmake config file generation

* changes to sdf specification from sdf8 (mostly sensors)
summary.html:
Backport from sdf8:

  • use cmake 3.5.1, major version in project name (sdformat7), use cmake targets and improve cmake config file generation

  • changes to sdf specification from sdf8 (mostly sensors)
